CARDINAL . The rules governing the powers , organisation and operation of social security courts and procedure before them are laid down in the Social Security Code . Alongside the general social security claims department there is a “ technical claims ” department which deals with claims concerning the existence or seriousness of a disability , the rate of permanent disability in the event of an occupational accident or disease and the incapacity to work taken into account by the old - age insurance scheme . Such claims are submitted in the first instance to the disability claims tribunal , and appeals are heard by the ORG , whose decisions are in turn subject to appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . Articles L. CARDINAL , NORP CARDINAL - CARDINAL , NORP CARDINAL - CARDINAL , NORP CARDINAL and NORP CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the Social Security Code stipulate that the ORG is composed of sections , each with CARDINAL members , as follows :

- one president , who is a practising or honorary administrative or ordinary court judge and is appointed for an indefinite period by joint decision of the Minister of ORG and the Minister responsible for ORG ( depending on the nature of the case being considered ) ;

- CARDINAL members who are practising or honorary administrative or ordinary court judges or A - grade civil servants from ORG responsible for ORG or for ORG , appointed by joint decision of the Minister of ORG and the Minister responsible for ORG ;

- CARDINAL non - presiding judges ( assesseurs ) , CARDINAL a salaried employee and CARDINAL an employer or self - employed person , appointed for DATE from a list drawn up by the Minister responsible for ORG , from candidates nominated by the most representative trade organisations concerned .

Article NORP CARDINAL stipulates that upon receipt of the notice of appeal the secretary of the tribunal shall invite the parties to present their written observations , in memorial form , within DATE , together , where applicable , with those of the doctor they have appointed to assist or represent them . The secretary is also responsible for transmitting the documents to the parties , or to the doctors appointed by them if the documents contain medical information . The parties may then submit further observations in reply within DATE .

CARDINAL . The section president appoints a rapporteur for each case from among the members of the section or possibly from a list of people drawn up by order of the Minister responsible for ORG , as appropriate . Rapporteurs who are not members of the section do not vote ( Article PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG must have any file submitted to it on appeal examined initially by an accredited doctor , chosen from a list drawn up by order of the Minister responsible for ORG . It may also consult qualified experts as and when deemed necessary . If it does this , the experts’ reports are communicated to each party , or to the doctors appointed by them if they are medical reports ( Articles R. CARDINAL - CARDINAL and PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . By virtue of Article NORP CARDINAL - CARDINAL the ministers responsible for ORG or their representatives “ may present written or oral observations ” to the court .

CARDINAL . Under Article NORP CARDINAL - CARDINAL the ORG “ shall rule solely on the basis of documents ” . No provision of ORG provides for the communication to the insured party of the report by the rapporteur or the opinion of the qualified doctor , who are appointed by the court under the above - mentioned Articles NORP CARDINAL - CARDINAL and NORP DATE .

CARDINAL ) , ORG of ORG found that the disability claims tribunal was not an independant and impartial tribunal within the meaning of LAW , as it was chaired by a civil servant answering to a hierarchy linked to the health insurance fund , which was a party to the claim .
CARDINAL . In his submissions in that case , for the attention of ORG , ORG stated , inter alia ( see Liaisons sociales , DATE , jurisp . no . CARDINAL ) :

“ This is not the first time [ LAW ] has been invoked before you in respect of the social security ’s technical claims departments . CARDINAL . In its DATE report ( p. CARDINAL , section on suggestions for legislative or regulatory amendments ) , published in DATE , ORG expressed doubts as to the compatibility of the procedure before the ORG with the guarantees of the right to a fair trial enshrined in LAW , in respect of :
- the composition of the tribunal , whose members include civil servants who are part of a hierarchy , in violation of the right to an independant and impartial tribunal ;
- the fact that it rules solely on the basis of documents , in violation of the principle of the public character of proceedings ;

- the prior examination of the file by an accredited doctor , which circumvents the adversarial principle if the opinion is not communicated to the parties . In this connection ORG considered that even if the accredited doctor did not have expert status , the communication of his opinion to a doctor the interested party has been invited to designate should be envisaged .

“ It is evident not only that the civil servants who sit on the ORG enjoy no specific guarantee as to their freedom of decision in the discharge of their judicial duties , but that the minister in charge of the administrative entity to which they belong has control over ORG through a directorate of his ministry and the regional directors of health and social affairs , who themselves , on behalf of the ORG and under the authority of the regional ORG , have control over the primary social security funds and the areas they cover .
However , the decisions challenged before the ORG are decisions of the social security funds , and these funds are more often than not also parties to the proceedings . ...

The fact that these civil servants are appointed for unlimited periods and that their judicial activities may be terminated at any time makes their situation more precarious and adds concern about their independence to the doubts about their impartiality .

... As regards the other categories of members of the ORG , their appointment by the Minister responsible for ORG or the fact that the minister draws up the list from which they are chosen , even if the trade organisations do make proposals DATE leaving the possibility for the minister to make choices DATE , the fact that they are all appointed for an unlimited period , which means that the minister can remove them at any time , including judges , who are therefore not irremovable , with the exception of those representing employees and employers , who are appointed for DATE but whose term of office the minister may or may not renew , and the lack of guarantees in the discharge of their judicial duties are all factors that undermine the independence and impartiality of this tribunal .
... What clearly applies to the composition of the ORG also applies to how it operates and could also be raised of the tribunal ’s own motion .

Thus does the national court actually operate with the compulsory assistance , in every case , of an “ accredited doctor ” and a rapporteur , who is generally not a member of the tribunal : however , not only are these collaborators remunerated on a case - by - case basis , from the budget of the Ministry in charge of ORG , but they are chosen from lists drawn up by the same ministry , and most of the rapporteurs are active or retired members of the ministry ’s staff , or active or former employees of the social security funds ...
